official-title.#text: To provide that certain uses of a patent or copyright in compliance with an order of the Federal Communications Commission for emergency communications services shall be construed as use or manufacture for the United States.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Protect Advanced Communications for Emergency Services Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

there are an estimated 302,000,000 active wireless mobile device users in the United States with an estimated 51,000,000 people in the United States living in households that rely solely on wireless communication devices (almost 25 percent of households in the United States), of which 21,000,000 are children;
people in the United States make more than 300,000 wireless E–9–1–1 (enhanced 9–1–1) calls daily;

a majority of 9–1–1 calls now originate from mobile devices, making an advanced wireless 9–1–1 service system a critical national asset for law enforcement, homeland security, and emergency responders who rely on this wireless location-based information to effectively dispatch assistance;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: mandates all wireless phone carriers and IP-enabled voice service providers to provide services enabling users to dial 9–1–1 with a stated purpose of allowing government first responders, homeland security, police, fire and other government public safety officials the ability to accurately locate 9–1–1 callers using wireless devices;

text.#text: the growing reliance of the people of the United States and public safety, homeland security, and law enforcement officials on emerging wireless technologies is leading to the need for national text to 9–1–1, as well as picture and video 9–1–1 capabilities from mobile devices;

emerging technologies can be a critical component of the end-to-end communications infrastructure connecting the public with emergency medical service providers and emergency dispatch providers, public safety, fire service, and law enforcement officials, and hospital emergency and trauma care facilities, to reduce emergency response times and provide appropriate care;
improved public safety remains an important public health objective of Federal, State, and local governments and substantially facilitates interstate and foreign commerce;
wireless carriers and their vendors, in complying with the Federal mandate to provide E–9–1–1 location-based technology, have become targets of or been impacted by patent infringement lawsuits;
patent infringement lawsuits brought by what the
compromising the ability of wireless carriers to provide current wireless 9–1–1 services; and
deterring the implementation of innovative new technologies that could meet next generation 9–1–1 public safety needs such as text, picture, and video 9–1–1 capabilities;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , was designed to protect those required by the Government to provide a service

quote.#tail: while also providing legitimate patent holders with an appropriate means to recover reasonable and entire compensation for their patents;
quote.#text: by or for the United States

text.#text: this Act clarifies that patented technologies required to provide 9–1–1, enhanced 9–1–1, and other emergency communications services, as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , are provided by and for the United States and with the authorization or consent of the United States for the purposes of

act-name.#text: Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999/s:7

text.#text: this Act does not modify or invalidate any patent, preserves all patent claims, and does not prevent patent litigation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following:

header.#text: Jurisdiction for claims regarding other emergency services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: against a wireless carrier subject to

text.#text: Beginning after the date of enactment of this subsection, any action under

external-xref.#tail: of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations, or any successor thereto, or an IP-enabled voice service provider subject to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , regarding the provision of 9–1–1, enhanced 9–1–1, or other emergency communications service (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 6(a) of the Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999/s:6/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ), shall be filed in accordance with this section.

header.#text: Jurisdiction for claims regarding 9–1–1, enhanced 9–1–1, or other emergency communications service
